credentials: PHD 1981 University of Texas at Austin
name: Paul Terry

ratings.comment: Good lecturer, teaches almost word-for-word from the textbook. Class is very fast-paced and math-heavy. Exams were incredibly difficult, the average grade on both midterms was about 50%. Homework wasn't really representative of exams.

Extremely organized lecturer. Really helpful and pleasant to speak to.

Exams average around 50% which is fine but the curve is pretty bad.

Homework was accepted a week late, but at a 50% point deduction. This was not mentioned in syllabus. His HW problems were generally good but the book problems can be frustrating and tedious.

Overall a solid professor. Not outstanding but far from the worst physics prof I've had. Basically lectures straight from the book. His exams were very fair and if you studied and went to lecture you will do well. Not an insanely hard course compared to other physics classes but it certainly could have been harder with a worse prof.

Paul is literally the best physics professor I've ever had. He cracks jokes during lecture and overall is a fun guy. He is here to have fun and he won't mind explaining to you how he's having fun in terms of turbulence. But nonetheless, take Paul. He's great, caring, and is an exceptional human being. His stories are great too!

Paul is clearly a passionate teacher, though a bit unorganized. If you are interested in the topics he is a great resource. He's not super clear on what all is fair game for homework and exams, so you do need to write down a lot, but he gives plenty of review for the exams, and tries to go over all of the homework in discussion.

Prof. Terry is a great professor, but the class is structured weird. The homeworks are pretty easy and simple to get done but the exams are a different world altogether. We consistenly had averages well below 50%. Also, the class is curved weird so that only 6 or so people out of 35 get an A and more people get AB than A, which is unfair.

So hard - the average on the 200 point final was 36, the highest score was 75. Goes through a lot of unrelated application material when the actual material is hard enough. Often makes mistake, but teaches straight from the book. Hard to fully understand the broad application of the concept for problems. Not a prof problem, just hard stuff.

In terms of Physics at UW-Madison, Prof Terry is probably the best professor I've had in this field so far. His lectures are solid, and even though he makes a lot of mistakes on the board, asking a question on how he got something will usually resolve it. Always ask questions. Going online was awful as his online class was just painful.

Not the best, not the worst. The only thing faster than the speed of light is the rate at which Paul lectures. Rarely stopping for questions (& frequently making errors), Paul lectures word-for-word from the textbook which makes it fairly easy to follow along with the material, but essentially renders the lectures useless. HW is OK, exams r tough.

Professor Terry is amazing. At first, you may be very scared by the content he presents, but don't worry. He is more than willing to meet outside of class, due to his very heavy interest in the topics that he teaches. If you put in the effort, he will see that and give you the needed attention in order to succeed.

Professor Terry is a sweet, sweet man. That being said, he failed to connect class demonstrations to the things we were actually tested on. A lot of what he presented was unclear and hard to follow, making it difficult to do well on the many homework assignments. He's frequently available outside of class but even that didn't provide much help.

Professor Terry doesn't spoon feed you. He is a good professor, but if you don't put any effort yourself and don't seek help, hoping you will do good on the tests, then you probably wont do well. The tests are VERY challenging, but he is available for help and when you do ask for help, Terry explains very well.
Not great.

Great prof. Very difficult, but worth it. Put in the work and you will get a good grade. Love physics. very passionate. Great one on one. Answers questions very well. One of my favorite Profs hands down. AMAZING. Would take again and again. Doesn't give many As or ABs, but well worth the sacrifice. Will learn a TON.
He lectures extremely fast straight from the book which makes the lectures basically pointless. The homework and tests are very hard. Tough class the way it is structured.

This man is very passionate about physics and is brilliant. Unfortunately, he has no memory of what it was like to not understand the material and moves way too fast as a result. This is a very difficult class.

Lectures very unorganized, and his teaching style is quite bad. His exams are so long or difficult that they are near impossible to finsih in the time allotted. Stay away if possible for 208. Mark is the way to go, since he has taught it more and is much clearer and concise
pretty much a helpless teacher, just read the book and do the homeworks then you'll easily get an AB. not necessarily need to attend the lectures

This class is great until Professor Terry takes over.  He is clearly well-meaning, but his lectures are poorly structured and difficult to follow.  Almost none of what he teaches in lecture is important for the test.  Just study from your homework and you'll be fine.

He's this nice old man, but you don't need to attend lecture since he'll explain stuff that's already in the book.  His exams were fair though...straight off the old practice exams.  And he responds very quickly to emails.

Note this is not a "real" physics class - it's music stuff! But, he provided some interesting information on this side interest of his, but a surprising amount of the physics he presented was inaccurate. Tests more difficult than they should have been. Required a 5 page paper... for a physics class!! Oh well, it was just BS anyway ;-).
very boring and useless to go to his lectures. just read the book he doesn't teach you anything.
